Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Dynamics of language processing and the consequences for new language learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the economy, society, and culture of the United States continue to take part in a larger global culture, it is becoming more important to learn languages spoken in other countries, as well as to improve the methods for teaching English as a second language to the families arriving to the United States. Children appear to be better at learning new languages than adults, who instead have very mixed outcomes in how well they ultimately learn a new language. For decades, research has attempted to understand why adults experience more difficulty in learning new languages and what characterizes good language learners compared to less successful language learners, so that we can use this information to improve teaching methods. From this research, we have learned how certain factors contribute to the outcomes in new language learning, but much of the variability remains unaccounted for, suggesting that there is still a piece of the puzzle missing. With National Science Foundation support, Ms. Kinsey Bice, working under the direction of Dr. Judith Kroll, will investigate how individual differences in learning may shape patterns of new second language learning.

The current project will examine how previous language experience combines with general cognitive resources to affect the trajectory of new language learning. Previous research has identified differences in the way that the native language is processed that may contribute to the trajectory of new language learning (i.e., fast and slow language learners), and that may also be affected by how speakers recruit various aspects of cognition (e.g., working memory, pattern abstraction) when processing their native language. This project will examine how these differences in skilled language processing predict the trajectory of new language learning, as well as whether the differences are related to variation in non-language abilities. Bilingual speakers, who already have experience with learning a new language and who do not use either language exactly as monolingual speakers do, have previously been found to be better at acquiring new languages, but bilinguals differ from each other in many ways that affect their language learning outcomes. This project will compare both monolingual and bilingual speakers in how they process their skilled languages and how they learn new languages. Behavioral methods and brain potentials will be used to determine whether the brain reflects some learning processes that are not apparent in behavior alone. The bilinguals tested will be typical college students who are taking advanced foreign language classes, as well as heritage Spanish speakers who are raised in Spanish-speaking homes but then educated in English. These two groups of bilinguals represent language experiences that American citizens often encounter themselves, while the monolingual groups will be recruited from parts of the United States that differ in the levels of ambient exposure to foreign languages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previous research has reported individual differences in adult language learning. Bilinguals acquire new languages better and faster than monolinguals, suggesting that being or becoming bilingual may contribute to their ability to learn additional languages. However, bilingualism is not uniform; bilingual experiences include differences in exposure, proficiency, literacy, and language learning experiences (e.g., classroom vs. immersion settings). The current study sought to better understand how individual differences in past language and learning experiences contribute to variation in new language learning. We included both early and late bilinguals with different previous language learning experiences and current linguistic profiles, and also monolinguals drawn from different linguistic contexts (central Pennsylvania, southern California).

Monolingual and bilingual participants learned words in Finnish over several sessions while their brain activity was recorded using electroencephalograms (EEGs). In addition to being a language equally unfamiliar to all participants, Finnish has a unique linguistic feature called vowel harmony, which prevents front vowels (ä, ö, y) from appearing in the same words as back vowels (a, o, u). Participants were taught vocabulary words in Finnish, but also implicitly learned to distinguish real Finnish words from vowel harmony violations. At test, they were asked to discriminate between real Finnish words and vowel harmony violations that they had learned during training in addition to novel words and violations that they had not previously encountered. Overall, the three groups had similar trajectories and outcomes of Finnish learning, although their brain responses suggest that the early and late bilinguals learned in fundamentally different ways that affected their event-related potentials (ERPs) during learning and at test.

In addition to the language learning task, we measured individual differences in how the brain processes the native language (and second language, for bilinguals). Past research has shown similar variation in brain responses (N400 and P600 components) to the native language as have been demonstrated in studies that examined the trajectory of brain responses during new language learning. While research on the native language has typically attributed these individual differences to variation in cognitive processes like working memory, our results suggest that proficiency is the primary factor influencing how the brain responds during language processing, in both the native language and in the second language of bilinguals. For our bilingual participants, brain responses in each language were correlated. Furthermore, the results showed that for the bilingual participants, brain responses in the less dominant language (Spanish) had a marginally significant positive relationship with their performance on the Finnish test, such that bilinguals with a larger P600 component in Spanish also had higher scores on the Finnish test of studied items.

We included a non-linguistic measure of category learning to identify individuals as explicit, rule-based learners or implicit, integration learners. Interestingly, 90% of the late bilinguals, who primarily learned their second language in a formal classroom environment, were explicit learners. Early bilinguals who relied on congruent learning strategies had better Finnish learning than early bilinguals who relied on explicit strategies. Implicit learning strategies were also related to more P600-dominant brain responses in English and Spanish. While these category learning tasks are not widely used in language research, our results suggest that they captured aspects of domain-general learning that have consequences for language processing and learning.

Finally, an important and unexpected result was found in comparing monolinguals living in central Pennsylvania and southern California. Monolinguals in each location had similar trajectories of learning Finnish, and similar performance at test for previously studied words. However, only the monolinguals living in southern California demonstrated sensitivity to the distinction between real Finnish words and vowel harmony violations that they had never seen before. Although behavioral performance was at chance for each group, brain responses of the California monolinguals revealed differences between novel words and violations. While we cannot say with certainty which specific aspect of language experience drove the effect (e.g., early exposure to multiple languages, number of languages in environment, continued exposure/immersion, interaction with non-native speakers, etc.), the results suggest diverse linguistic contexts support new language learning, even for languages that are not present in that context.

This research contributes to our understanding of how varied language experience shapes future learning experiences, both linguistic and domain-general. Early and late bilinguals revealed different patterns of results, confirming that bilingualism is not categorical but varies with learning and language experience. The early bilinguals were heritage speakers of Spanish, and by including them we have gained insight into heritage language use, maintenance, and literacy, and their consequences for brain function. Furthermore, monolinguals’ language experiences may also be shaped by their linguistic environments, even in the absence of active bilingualism. In summary, these findings hone our understanding of the complexities of past and current language experiences, and how language and domain-general functions work together to contribute to new language learning.
